title: Judgment on Egypt
shortSummary: Ezekiel 30 delivers a prophetic oracle announcing God's impending judgment on Egypt and its allies through the hand of Babylon. The chapter vividly portrays the destruction and desolation that will come upon Egypt, emphasizing God's sovereignty and the certainty of His righteous judgment. This serves as a solemn warning about the consequences of pride and idolatry.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the Babylonian exile, shortly before the fall of Egypt's influence

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh king of Egypt
keyCharacters.description: The ruler of Egypt who is symbolically depicted as having a broken arm, representing his weakened power and impending defeat.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
keyCharacters.description: The Babylonian king whom God uses as an instrument of judgment to bring destruction upon Egypt.

keyCharacters.name: Son of man (Ezekiel)
keyCharacters.description: The prophet Ezekiel, who receives and delivers God's message of judgment against Egypt.

definitions.definition: A title used by Ezekiel referring to himself, emphasizing his humanity and role as God's prophet.
A future time of God's decisive judgment and intervention in human affairs.
Physical representations or images worshiped as gods, which God declares He will destroy in Egypt.
Symbolizes strength and power; a broken arm indicates loss of power and defeat.

outline.heading: Introduction and Call to Lament
outline.description: God commands Ezekiel to prophesy a lament over the coming day of the LORD, described as a cloudy and dark day signifying judgment on the nations, particularly Egypt.

outline.heading: Judgment Pronounced on Egypt and Allies
outline.description: A detailed prophecy of destruction against Egypt and its neighboring allies, including Ethiopia and Libya, highlighting the devastation by the sword and the breaking of Egypt’s foundations.

outline.heading: Desolation of Key Egyptian Cities and Idols
outline.description: God declares the destruction of Egyptian idols and cities such as Noph, Pathros, Zoan, and No, emphasizing the totality of judgment and the resulting fear and captivity.

outline.heading: The Broken Arm of Pharaoh and Babylon’s Rise
outline.description: God reveals that Pharaoh’s power is broken and will not be restored, while Babylon’s strength will be empowered to conquer Egypt, scattering its people and demonstrating God’s sovereignty.

application: Recognize that God is sovereign over all nations and that pride and reliance on human power apart from Him leads to downfall.
Trust in God's righteous judgment and submit to His authority, knowing that He uses even foreign powers to accomplish His purposes.
Avoid idolatry in any form, understanding that God will bring judgment on all who place anything above Him.
Pray for humility and repentance, both personally and corporately, to avoid the fate of those who reject God's commands.

keyVerses.text: For the day is near, even the day of the LORD is near, a cloudy day; it shall be the time of the heathen.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the tone for the chapter, emphasizing the imminent and unavoidable judgment of God on the nations.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the Lord GOD; I will also make the multitude of Egypt to cease by the hand of Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God's use of Babylon as His instrument of judgment against Egypt, underscoring divine sovereignty over world powers.

keyVerses.text: Son of man, I have broken the arm of Pharaoh king of Egypt; and, lo, it shall not be bound up to be healed, to put a roller to bind it, to make it strong to hold the sword.
keyVerses.significance: This verse symbolizes the permanent weakening of Egypt’s power and the certainty of its defeat.

keyVerses.text: And I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, and disperse them among the countries; and they shall know that I am the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: It concludes the prophecy by affirming that God's judgment will lead to recognition of His sovereignty.
